title: Inappropriate for judges to intervene in prorogation, says government lawyer
text:
There are areas of political process that cannot be subjected to judicial standards, supreme court hears

It is constitutionally inappropriate for the courts to intervene in the prime minister’s decision to prorogue parliament for five weeks because there is a clear separation of powers, the supreme court has been told by a government lawyer.

On the second day of its emergency hearing, Sir James Eadie QC, representing Boris Johnson, argued there were areas of political process and “high policy” that could not be subjected to any judicial standards.

But Eadie conceded it was legitimate for the courts to ascertain whether use of prerogative powers should be subject to judicial review.

Lord Kerr, one of the justices, challenged Eadie by saying: “So there are constraints to the [prerogative] power and it is the purpose and role of the court to consider whether those [powers] have been exceeded?” Eadie accepted that role.

Kerr continued: “Let us suppose the prime minister decided for political reasons that he did want to stifle debate and did want to avoid scrutiny of his actions and he decided to prorogue for a year.”

Would that not constitute grounds for the courts to intervene, Kerr asked.

Q&A What is the UK supreme court and how does it work? Show Hide The supreme court of the United Kingdom was formally established on 1 October 2009. It is the ultimate court for hearing cases of the greatest public or constitutional importance, and is the final court of appeal in the UK, except for criminal cases heard in Scotland. The supreme court took over the judicial functions of the House of Lords, separating the judiciary from the legislature. It brought an end to the system of appealing to the "lords of appeal in ordinary" - commonly known as the law lords. The court comprises the president and deputy president and 10 other judges of the supreme court. Judges are appointed by the Queen on the advice of the prime minister, to whom a name is recommended by a special selection commission. The prime minister is obliged to recommend this name. The judgments in all decided cases from the court are published on the court's website.

Eadie agreed that parliamentary sovereignty was a “precious” concept but added that it was no good “turning up and shouting about parliamentary sovereignty” because the phrase could mean different things. It can mean simply that parliament can “make and unmake its own laws”. He said the common law did not, and should not, regulate the scheduling of parliamentary proceedings.

Eadie said the only “sure and proper guide” for courts to intervene in cases was on the basis of already enacted legislation. Otherwise, he maintained, it moved the courts into the territory of “parliamentary controversy”.

Eadie continued: “Parliament has been considering Brexit for months and years. It has had the opportunity to make whatever legislative provisions it wants over that period.” He said parliament could have taken action to resist being closed down. “Legislation could have been added to control the prorogation after it had been introduced.”

Lord Wilson said it was extraordinary no witness statement had been given to the supreme court confirming that the cabinet minutes giving reasons for prorogation were correct.

“No one has come forward to say this is true,” Wilson stressed. “They [the documents] are just floating around. Isn’t it odd that no one has signed a witness statement that this is true? That these are the true reasons for what is done?”

But Eadie said it was not normal for ministers to provide such witness statements. “No one has suggested that they are not the proper documents we need,” he said.

“There are a myriad of reasons for the length of this prorogation. Reading these documents the evident aim was everyone was concerned to get to a place where a Queen’s speech was produced.”

Lady Arden, a supreme court justice, asked what the situation would be where a government prorogued parliament for one reason and then extended it for much longer for a different purpose. “Are you saying that the courts would have no role in that situation?” she asked Eadie.

The government’s leading lawyer replied: “I am. Our case is that this is political territory. It’s not about judging the sufficiency [of the reasons] or the length of the prorogation. We submit that it’s for the government to regulate the sessions of parliament.”

The supreme court case has generated widespread interest. The first members of the public began queueing at 6.30am on Wednesday to secure a seat in court. The livestreamed broadcast of the proceedings in court attracted more than 4m requests to view during the course of Tuesday morning’s hearing.

In written submissions, Lord Garnier QC, representing the former prime minister John Major, said it would be remarkable if the courts took the view “that there is nothing in law to prevent a prime minister from proroguing parliament in any circumstances or for any reason”.

He added: “The fact that there are constitutional safeguards which operate on the well-intentioned [prime minister] is no reason for the courts to reject any possibility of intervening even in other cases.”

Garnier continued: “The reason why these proceedings are necessary at all is that the power of prorogation subverts the possibility of control by political means. Its effect is to deprive parliament of a voice throughout the period of the prorogation …

“The court is under no obligation to approach this case on the artificially naive basis that the handful of disclosed documents, which no one has been prepared to verify with a statement of truth, should nevertheless be assumed to be entirely accurate and complete even when members of the cabinet do not appear to believe them.”

Lawyers for the shadow attorney general, Shami Chakrabarti, put in fresh submissions on Wednesday, stating: “The exercise of power to prorogue parliament has the potential to affect/undermine parliament’s ability to carry out its constitutional function of holding the executive to account and therefore engages the overarching principle of parliamentary sovereignty.”

The submission also contained a list of 13 bills that were before parliament before prorogation. They include the divorce, dissolution and separation bill and the domestic abuse bill.

The hearing continues.
